pullRequest.body:
From the Hairer challenge

+ add `flip_in/sur/bijective_iff₁₂`: if either of the spaces V and W is finite-dimensional, a linear map `V → W*` is injective/surjective/bijective iff the flipped map `W → V*` is surjective/injective/bijective.

+ also add consequence for SeparatingDual from the [projective space thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Projective.20space/near/392642695) (cc @smorel394)

+ remove the `FiniteDimensional` condition from `dual_finrank_eq`, `finrank_range_dualMap_eq_finrank_range`, and `dualMap_injective/bijective_iff`, completing two TODO items by @kmill

+ add two lemmas `toDual_injective` and `finite_dual_iff`

+ golf several proofs in LinearAlgebra/Dual

Co-authored-by: Kyle Miller <kmill31415@gmail.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I've now spun out another PR #9124 based on this one. If everything looks good can we merge this soon?

:v: alreadydone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

As this PR is labelled `auto-merge-after-CI`, we are now sending it to bors:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7250642103/job/19751283956)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7250642103/job/19751285018)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7250642103/job/19751283571)

In my latest [commit](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8820/commits/12aa88dd56cd74772903347fcc77397fccfec67c) I golfed some proofs and managed to remove the FiniteDimensional condition from `dual_finrank_eq`, `finrank_range_dualMap_eq_finrank_range`, and `dualMap_injective/bijective_iff`, completing two TODO items by @kmill. I think they're within scope as they are very relevant to the `flip` results and even used to prove them. Also cc @themathqueen (author of [#18228](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/18228))

The only thing I really would like to see before merging is that you more clearly document that TODO item.

Thanks!

bors d+

You can generalize this to these:
```lean
theorem injective_flip_iff [FiniteDimensional K V₁] {B : V₁ →ₗ[K] V₂ →ₗ[K] K} :
    Function.Injective B.flip ↔ Function.Surjective B := by
  rw [← dualMap_surjective_iff]
  rw [← Equiv.surjective_comp (Module.evalEquiv K V₁).toEquiv]
  rfl

theorem surjective_flip_iff [FiniteDimensional K V₂] {B : V₁ →ₗ[K] V₂ →ₗ[K] K} :
    Function.Surjective B.flip ↔ Function.Injective B := by
  rw [← injective_flip_iff]
  rfl
```
They can go right after `LinearMap.dualMap_surjective_iff`.

I think it's nicer stating them as bilinear forms directly rather than using `Module.Dual`, since `flip` unfolding the definition is a little obscure.

(Do you think these can be generalized further?)

Unfortunately, you're proving different results than what I want; I'd like to have [FiniteDimensional K V₁]` instead (V1 rather than V2) in
```
theorem surjective_flip_iff [FiniteDimensional K V₂] {B : V₁ →ₗ[K] V₂ →ₗ[K] K} :
```
Your version is more restrictive, because if V2 is f.d. and B is injective, then V1 is also f.d., while my version allows the possibility of V2 being infinite dimensional. ~~I can't think of a shorter proof of my version at this moment ...~~ (Update: I've obtained a one-line proof, using `dualMap_injective_iff` instead.)

I think your results are still interesting and I'll include them. To distinguish with my version (upgraded to iff), I will use subscripts 1 and 2 to indicate which space needs to be finite dimensional. I'll use the name `flip_surjective_iff` following the convention of `dualMap_surjective_iff` etc. 

I think the result probably generalize to division rings if you put a mop somewhere, but I'm not in a position to generalize the Dual file ...

Ah, ok, I wasn't looking carefully enough that only one was using the finite dimensionality hypothesis. By the way, I just became aware of the PerfectPairing module due to #8824. There's a `flip` specifically for maps to the dual over there.

It's mentioned in the PR title :) It might be the case that reflexivity is a more natural setting for all these results than f.g. free modules or f.d. vector spaces, and if true we could consider another PR to change everything systematically.
I haven't checked in lean, but I'm guessing the syntax would be `congrm ∀ v, ?_`, which I think is more readable.
It works, thanks!
Is this a TODO? Could you state it as one? (I like adding my github username like in `TODO (kmill)` so that someone can later ping me if they want.)
added TODO

Technically we shouldn't do this kind of cosmetic modification in a feature PR, but since `$` seems to have gone out of fashion (and since it doesn't make my reviewing any harder) I'm fine with it.

Better would have been using `<|` since that captures the original author's intent. Using parentheses is something they could have used back in Lean 3, so why switch to parentheses now?

Anyway, don't change your PR. I'm just leaving this comment as a very mild warning.

Yeah people have been requesting switching from $ to <| in PR reviews, so since I was at it, I just took the liberty to fix these few. I hope the author @ocfnash is okay with the changes! (In fact this was added directly to mathlib4 in [#4989](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/e6733eceaa63e98580cb8b30029664641347ce06#diff-1a470a10fd05f0eedb570bfbbe37c36b1a2472e9dc4c78aa7fc070d33ec2c2d2R591-R593).) As for why I changed it to parentheses instead of <|, it's because I don't see the point of using <| (which consumes one more character) when there's no nested parentheses at all.
I’m travelling sans laptop so do what you like 😀

The main purpose of my comment was to mention a principle that I think is important to follow: in a feature PR, do not make unrelated cosmetic changes or style improvements.

I hope nobody has been requesting switching `$` to `<|` on unrelated lines not touched by a PR. This is what style PRs are for.

My point was *if* you're going to break this rule and have activities outside [the type of the commit](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/commit.html), then I think it's better if you are conservative about it (hence why I suggested that sticking to an analogous style would be better).
I see, thanks for the clarification!

Something like this probably works. You might even be able to put a forall into the `congr(...)` and remove the `ext`.
```suggestion
  ⟨φ.comp f', ext fun x ↦ congr(φ $hf' x)⟩
```
This is not something you need to change for this PR though.
Thanks! `congr(φ <| $hf' x)` works.
